segments.text: This is an interview with Mr. Billy Pete Huddleston by Dwayne Purvis on May the 6th at the Petroleum Engineering Building at Texas A&M.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I am asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
That will be fine.
All right.
Let's talk a little bit about your background.
Were you born and raised?
I was born in a small West Texas town of Ira Ann, I-R-A-A-N.
It was named after Ira and Ann Yates.

Ira Ann also happens to be about the center of the Yates oil field, which is one of the largest oil fields in the North American continent, and still has the well that tested at the highest flow rate that's ever been tested in the North American continent, over 250,000 barrels per day.
That's incredible.
So you grew up around there a little?
I grew up in the field itself.
I was actually born in an oil field camp in what they call their nurse's quarters, delivered by an oil field lady that was called a midwife that delivered all the children in the camp.
In fact, I've got a photograph of the 82 children that she delivered in that one oil field camp.
busy camp.
Yeah, right.
Then you went to A&M for your undergraduate?
I graduated from RN High School in 1952.
I came to A&M on a football scholarship and studied petroleum engineering.
I took some additional courses and graduated in five years.
I ended up with 180 hours, but it was all in undergraduate work.
I was not doing any graduate work at all.
I'd worked in the summers beginning when I was 12 years old
and pulling units, which is oil field equipment.
By the time I was 15, I'd graduated to working on rotary rigs, and so I worked as a roughneck until I graduated from A&M.
And I worked myself up as a relief driller, which is the highest position that you could get on the last summer that I worked prior to graduation.
What year did you graduate?
I graduated from A&M in 1957.
I was employed by Marathon Oil Company.
I started in East Texas, went to Mississippi, North Louisiana, Arkansas.
Someplace in there, I had a two-year leave of absence.
I served in a fighter interceptor squadron with the Air Defense Command in the United States.
I was stationed in Massachusetts on Cape Cod, later at an Air Force base in Roswell, New Mexico.
I went back to Marathon.
I worked for them at South Louisiana, Texas Gulf Coast, and South Texas.
I resigned from Marathon in 1965.
I was 30 years old and formed my own business.
Farmed Huddleston Company.
It's consulting petroleum engineers.
Had a lot of work almost immediately.
Farm grew somewhat slowly.
1971, I formed Peter Paul Petroleum Company that still exists today.
Principal partner in Peter Paul Petroleum Company is Princeton University Endowment Fund.
We manage
for our joint accounts, about $100 million worth of oil and gas properties.
So we're very active.
Good.
You're very active in small fields?
Mostly small fields.
We do not participate in offshore.
We don't do deep drilling.
But we do drill a good many wells.
But rarely do we drill below 12,000 feet.
And we do not drill anything offshore.
OK.
Looking back to 1965, what was the condition of the industry
Condition in the industry was quite depressed.
The reason that I left Marathon, it was strange, I actually was promoted.
I was a district reservoir engineer at Bay City, Texas, and I had been promoted to the international reservoir engineer, which was a giant promotion for me.
Unfortunately, that job was located in New York City.

and so i resigned in those days if you did not accept a promotion with the company then you were essentially going to be stagnant so i resigned moved to houston i had three small children uh industry was quite depressed oil was selling for two dollars and eighty cents a barrel the gas was selling for 12 14 cents in mcf in fact in 19
69, I believe, was the lowest number of graduates in petroleum engineering that we ever had from A&M.
I think we graduated 18 engineers.
My graduating class, by contrast, we had 73 in my graduating class.
73 in the 50s?
In petroleum engineering.
Wow.
So the market continued to be bad for several years?
The market was, the industry was very depressed until 1973.
Why was it depressed until 73?
There was an excess supply of oil.
In fact, in the early 60s, there was so much excess oil that the Texas Railroad Commission prorated or limited the amount of production that could be produced.
And they called it so many producing days.
We got down as low as you could only produce eight days a month.
and your wells had to be shut in the other 22 days a month.
Actually, they would let you prorate over the entire period, but you could only produce it like 25, 26% of what the well was capable of producing.
Was there no proration before the 1960s?
No, there was proration, but we just had ended up with an excess, more and more excess oil.
And so in order to keep the price
from just absolutely going to 10 cents a barrel or something, then they cut back production and that stabilized the price.
In fact, the Texas Railroad Commission, although they denied it, was the first OPEC.
They were the first oil cartel all by themselves.
So where was Texas oil coming from?
If Texas was choked back, where was the oil coming from?
Well, even at producing at that level of production, Texas is 35% of the total oil in the United States.
And so choking Texas back to 25% of their capability, then we were producing only enough oil to meet the demand.
But 75% of Texas production was shut in then.
And so the industry was very depressed because we had an excess of oil and very low prices.
a very low income level, and it stayed that way until 1973 when the Arabs put an embargo of oil on the United States.
What year was OPEC formed?
Well, it probably was formed in, I don't know, maybe prior to 1970, but they really did not have any power.
I mean, we were importing probably 40% of our oil, but they actually cut off
All of our supply, OPEC cut off all of our supply in 1973.
So before that, so OPEC first exercised its power in 1973.
Before that, it didn't exercise its power either positively or negatively.
That's correct.
Okay.
Their first impact was in 1973, and when they cut off the oil supply, we immediately had a monstrous gasoline shortage.
there would be sometimes it would take you two or three hours of waiting in line just to get gasoline and that was common all over the United States in 1973.
Price of oil immediately went to six dollars a barrel, went from less than three to over six dollars a barrel.
At that point also Texas had run out of spare capacity and essentially was up to a hundred percent of capacity
up from, remember they'd had 75% of their production shut in in the late 50s, early 60s.
So Texas was at 100% of capacity.
The oil price had now doubled to $6 a barrel.
So we began in 73 to be really good economic years for the petroleum industry through 1985.
A lot of new companies started in 1973?
A lot of companies.
Prior to 1973, we had about 4,000 independent companies.
By 1978, we had 12,000 independent companies.
Did they go big again?
Well, we stayed at 12,000 until 1986 when the price of oil broke down dramatically.
It came down from
In 1981, it was $37 a barrel.
It went down to $27 a barrel by 85.
And then in January of 86, oil went to $10 to $12 a barrel.
And by 1990, the 12,000 independents had gone way down to about 4,000 independents.
We're probably about 3,000 today.
How did the strategy of the majors change?
Well, the majors of course increased their drilling budget dramatically.
They began to drill what we call frontier basins in the United States that previously had not really been drilled.
Some of these basins were like the deep smack over Norflet production in Alabama, Mississippi.
These are
oil and gas fields that are below 17,000-18,000 feet.
They began to drill the deep Anadarko.
Why weren't they drilling gas in 1973?
Well, the price of gas had gone up dramatically, too.
Oil went up, it didn't go up as much as oil, did it?
Yes, percentage-wise, the price of gas in 1967-68
was about 26 cents.
By 1971 it had gone up to 75 to 80 cents.
Now 73 had gone up to a dollar and a half.
So it went up tenfold in a period of about five, six years.
Why did gas demand go up so much?
For a different reason from oil, is that there we thought that there was a
great glut of gas in the United States, but beginning in 1971, and there was a lot of industries, and of course a lot of residential use of gas, we ran dramatically short of gas.

The price of gas had been controlled solely by the Federal Power Commission, which is now the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, and it was treated as a utility price, and it was strictly controlled by the federal government.
Drilling for gas had lagged way behind, and we went dramatically short of gas.
In fact, in the winter of 71-72, perhaps 72-73, we had such a shortage of gas that the University of Texas was actually shut down for over a week.
The city of San Antonio was virtually shut down for over a week due to gas shortage.
So at that time people were paying a buck and a half for gas and it was still controlled, still price controlled?
Well there was intrastate gas that did not flow across the state boundaries, was not controlled.
So as a consequence, very little new gas was committed to flow across state lines to like St. Louis or Chicago.
and the utilization of it for a short period of time was solely within the state to get around cost control.
I see.
So, okay, so all embargo hits and everybody goes drilling.
They didn't drill very many development fields, mostly frontiers?
Well, you were asking about the change in strategy of the major.
Is that?
When their drilling budget went up dramatically, remember their cash flow has now more than doubled what it has been.
And typically what we use is what we call a plowback ratio, is that the majors usually plow back about 50% of their total cash flow into new drilling activity.
So they more than doubled their drilling budget in a very short period of time.
They didn't have enough development drilling
to be able to utilize that much cash flow.
So that's why they started drilling the deep frontier type of prospects.
Deep Rocky Mountains became very active which had not seen much activity.
Offshore had a tremendous boom because offshore drilling had been very expensive.
Did this drilling boom affect other industries in the U.S.?

It affected, well, probably two major industries, the fabricating business that were building platforms and equipment, and it affected the service companies, which is the Halliburton's, Lumberjays, the people that are servicing the rigs and furnishing pipe and this type of thing.
How did the employment in the industry change during the early drilling days?
Employment in the petroleum industry in 1970 was probably around at the $300,000 mark.
By 1975, it had grown to like $350,000, as I recall.
Something on that order.
Not a great change.
Not a great change.
Of course, we probably had a surplus of people actually coming into that.
They just put them to work.
Now, then the big buildup,
was that by 1981, we went from 350,000 to over 700,000 people.
More than double the employment there in a six year period.
Doesn't sound wise.
No, it wasn't.
The oil embargo ended in 74, is that right?
It was very short, a short period of time.
Probably ended in late 73 or early 74.
How did strategy change then?
Well, there was

A general feeling that we could drill ourselves, well, I would say this is a consensus, but a lot of people thought that we could drill ourselves into what we call an independent state, that we would not have to import any oil.
I was not one of those people.
I never thought that we had enough reserves in the United States to become close to becoming independent.
But there was a lot of drilling activity.
A lot of it aimed domestically.
The drilling budgets continued to increase, probably peaked out in about 1981 or 1982.
Oil price fell back?
The oil price peaked in 1981 at $37 a barrel.
To a climb from $73 to $81?
Consistently, yes.
Even after the embargo ended?
Yes.
Well, the reason is that OPEC had the threat of shutback all the time.
And all they had to do was to curtail their production just a little bit, and they could run the price of oil up.
Total production in the world is about, even then, was someplace in the low 60 million barrels a day.
OPEC controlled 25 million barrels a day.
Texas Railroad Commission had controlled the price in the 40s, 50s, and 60s.
Now OPEC can control the price by simply shutting back production the same way the Texas Railroad Commission did.
So everybody was tens and therefore prices stayed high?
Yes.
There was plenty of oil.
It was simply the threat of shutting it back.
OPEC could do the same thing today.
If OPEC, that's producing 24 million barrels a day, were to cut back a million barrels
production, less than 5% of their production, the price of oil would go over $20 a barrel.
It's currently about $17.
They can increase the price of oil immediately in less than 24 hours.
Incredible.
So during this whole time, people are speculating and keeping prices high?
The overwhelming consensus in the petroleum industry
All of the projections, including the DOE, all of the major financial houses such as Barrel Lane, Solomon, in 1980 are predicting by the mid-90s that oil will be $60 a barrel.
So budgets were based, built on these price forecasts.
The petroleum industry from 1979 through 1985 overspent
what their previous level of expenditures had been, about $20 million a year, they overspent $160 billion in exploration and development.
And as a result, they got nothing for it.
Looking over the table of numbers, I saw two years where there was an increased reserves and every other year it declined.
Right.
The first increase was 1979.
That's the largest increase.
It's about 10%.
Was that infield drilling or was that new fields?
A lot of it was infield drilling.
Actually, where wells had been originally drilled on, say, 80-acre spacing, they came in and drilled them on 40-acre spacing.
But you'll see that there's from 70...
it was 27.1 billion barrels, and they increased it to 80 to 29.8 billion, and essentially after that it began to decline with little blips in there.
But while you're saying, remember we spent during that period of time $160 billion extra over our normal budget.
So we're spending a lot more for almost nothing.
Essentially nothing, yeah.
I remember seeing a chart that showed major oilfield discoveries, fields discovered that were over 200 million barrels.
And as I recall, the only fields of more than 200 million barrels discovered in the U.S. after the early 70s were Alaska.
That's correct.
So we've gone over the hump and found basically all the fields in the U.S.
There's no question about that.
We may have a few fields
left primarily offshore, and a lot of it in very deep water, water as deep as 3,000 feet in the 50 to 100 million barrel range.
I do not know of any prospects today onshore that are greater than 25 million barrels.
Well, in the time period when prices were escalating, we were spending more money on research and development, or not research, but exploration and development.
Was there anything the government could have done to keep the price down, or what did it do to keep the price down?
Well, actually, the government really didn't do much to pricing.
They did just the opposite effect.
In 1980, thereabout, no, early 1973, they essentially put price controls on oil, in that all of your profit over a certain level
was taxed by what they call a windfall profits tax up to 70%.
For example, they said, we'll put a base on your oil at $6 a barrel.
When oil went to $20 a barrel, the $14 a barrel was taxed away from the oil companies at 70%.
So they didn't control the price of oil.
They simply taxed away any excess income.
They did not put an excise tax on gas.
They still had price controls on most of the flowing gas in the United States as late as 1989.
It was controlled by the Natural Gas Policy Act.
It was enacted in 1978.
There were strict price controls on gas.
What did the 78 Act do?
Well, it put price controls on gas.
Which hadn't been there before?
Well, there were different types of price controls.
We had area pricing rates.
For example, in, say, the panhandle of Texas, you could sell gas for 15 cents.
In South Texas, you could sell it for 14 cents.
In 1978, they created some 20 different categories of gas depending upon the vintage and the depth.
In other words, Wells Drill prior to 1978 got an old low price, 40 cents.
Wells Drill after 1978 got to sell for $2.
So they had a nightmare of pricing.
They said they had some 20 categories of gas.
We actually identified 37 different categories of gas.
depending on depth, how close it was to another field, another well, date drilled, all types of things.

So to a large extent, whatever the government did in respect to its foreign policy wouldn't have done that much to change the domestic oil and gas behavior because international politics didn't have a lot to do with their profits.
Not really.
I guess that they could have had some impact if they had threatened OPEC, you know, with force or something.
And there was some early on, of course, there were some rumblings when they put an embargo on it.
So we need to send the army in there and take over the fields in Saudi Arabia.
But I don't think it had very much support, really.
Probably been a good idea.
It sounds nice.
So when did, how long was gas regulation in place?
Gas regulation was effectively in place from 1978 through 1989.

All gas in the United States is now deregulated and what helped bring that on is that we thought that there was a tremendous shortage of gas and there was when they put the increased gas prices in effect in 1978.
There was a big surge in drilling

and by 1982 or three in a very short period of time we had created a lot of gas reserves and 84 beginning in late 84 we had what we called a gas bubble we had an excess of gas supply in the united states so now gas begins to sell in 1985 below the ceiling prices that have been brought out to the government in other words they're not even selling at the highest

price that you could sell for and the gas price continued to deteriorate from 85 finally in 1989 congress says take all the controls off because we don't need them there's no gas being sold at those prices anyway so all gas today is deregulated so it was a one-step deal it started at 78 and ended in 89 yes tell me about the type of gas contracts that existed before 1989 uh
Actually, your contracts changed dramatically in 1985 when we had the excess.
Prior to 1985, typically a gas contract to buy from any well was for a period of 15 to 20 years, some of them for the duration of the life of the well.
When we got to an excess of gas, then the gas companies
that were buying the gas no longer wanted to be committed to long-term contracts because they had excess supply.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission passed a regulation that said that the customers were no longer obligated to honor their purchase contracts
with the gas companies, that they could buy gas from anybody in the United States, regardless, even if they had committed themselves to buy gas from a gas company for 15 years.
They set aside those contracts.
And the net effect of that is that it put all gas on what we call the spot market.
And contracts, as we knew them prior to 1985, were essentially abandoned.
Virtually all gas today is sold on a spot market.
contract to sell your gas every month just for the next month.
Was it better off for the buyers and better off for the sellers on the spot or on the long-term contract?
Well, the seller, it was better off on the long-term contract because you knew what price that you were going to get for a long period of time.
Were they going to get better prices too?
They were going to get better prices under the contracts, but essentially all of those contracts have been set aside and

court has just nullified many of them and said that you will sell your gas on the spot market at a lower price did the did the sellers sue oh yes there was billions and billions of dollars of litigation the producers that had long-term contracts early on won the lawsuits probably in the first year or so but after that they've consistently lost what was the result of that
Well, the result of it, of course, is that it broke a lot of producers that had gone out and spent a lot of money drilling expensive wells in anticipation of selling their gas for $3.
When the court sent their contract aside and they had to sell it for $1, $1.50, they could not pay their bank debt off that they'd incurred to drill the wells, and they went broke.
The 80s saw a lot of buyouts and mergers.
happen a lot in oil and gas?
Yes, there was a tremendous consolidation in the 80s.
Many major oil companies sold out.
Marathon Oil Company sold out to U.S. Steel.
Texas Oil and Gas sold out to U.S. Steel.
Comico was taken over by DuPont.
Gulf was taken over by Chevron.
City service was taken over by Occidental.
Would those have happened if gas had not been deregulated?
Probably.
It was inevitable.
We had a lot of excess infrastructure in the petroleum industry, in the domestic industry.
If you go back and look, you can see that oil production particularly has declined steadily.
So there had to be some retrenchment.
We simply had too much at the top, frankly, and maybe too many people at the bottom, too, and so this is what brought about the consolidations.
And we're going to continue to have consolidations.
Were the consolidations good for the industry?
I would say they were necessary.
If you lost your job, you know, you certainly didn't think it was good for the industry or good for anything, but there was just no question because the
declining profitability, there had to be a consolidation.
So in order to survive, to keep any type of profitability level, there had to be consolidation.
And that probably would have happened even without deregulation.
Yes.
You said a lot of people lost their jobs during the restructuring?
Oh gosh, 350,000 people.
We've lost half of the industry since 1981.
Was that because of restructuring or because of prices?
Or were the two separate?
Both.
The prices continued to deteriorate.
Production continued to decline.
So obviously in order to keep some level of profitability, you had to have a whole lot less people, which is the single most expensive component in the production of oil and gas.
I remember, back to the gas, which got me into that idea, I remember hearing that the pipelines were opened up and made available to every producer equally.
That's correct.
When did that happen?
Well, actually, that was Order 636, and it just happened this last year.
There's been a series of orders, but in effect,
The whole structure of the gas pipeline industry, which is Enron, ANR, Texas Eastern, Panhandle Eastern, Florida Gas, Transwestern, El Paso, these are your major pipeline companies.
They had served for many years prior to just last year's what we call merchant gas companies in that they went and signed up a lot of long-term contracts with lots of producers.

They aggregated that gas, and then they turned around and made long-time sales contracts with a lot of major industries in a lot of major cities, Chicago, Detroit, New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, and so on.
With 636 called the unbundling of services, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said that the gas companies could no longer serve in a merchant function, that

the end users of gas could contact the producer or any gas sales and buy gas directly from them and the gas pipeline that was hooked up to those wells was obligated to transport that gas to the customer.
Now they could charge a transportation fee but at that point we no longer had merchant gas companies and essentially you've had producers selling directly to end users now.
So were the
Were the merchant gas transporters held liable for violation of contract?
Oh, yes.
They lost early on when the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission first took the position that the end user, the customer, no longer had to satisfy their purchase contracts.
They said, you're excused out of buying this gas, even though you've got 15 years left on it.
The pipelines were not excused from their contracts from the producer.
To buy.
To buy.
So there they had gone out and bought billions of dollars worth of gas under long-term contract, and they had no customer on the other end that was obligated to buy it.
So did we lose a lot of gas transporters?
We didn't lose.

any gas transporters but they lost billions and billions of dollars columbia for example the major gas transmission line is in bankruptcy today transco came very close to bankruptcy the and the gas companies consistently lost their cases fighting the contracts in court with the producers in the early years in the last four or five years they've had a lot more success but they're still losing cases still losing cases so are these are
Were they able to make a surcharge to the user to help pay for their indebtedness?
No.
They simply said the end user does not have to buy the gas anymore.
They can buy it any place if they find it cheaper.
But when the pipeline said, OK, we'll pass the second rule that lets us out of our contracts with the producer, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission told them, that's your problem.
So why were the gas transporters the one that took the hit?
Well, nobody really knows.
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission only addressed half of the problem and refused to address the other half of the problem.
No understanding why?
No.
They just said, that's not our problem.
Our problem is to protect the end user.
And that's between the producer and the pipeline company.
You'll just have to fight your problems out in court.
How did the changes in bankruptcy law in the late 70s change our business?
Probably the largest single change is they gave what we call in Chapter 11 presenting the debtor in possession a lot greater latitude than they had in previous years.
For example, as companies began to go into bankruptcy, previous years they could be forced to sell their assets.
And whatever they get for them, they give it to their creditors.

In the late 70s, early 80s, Chapter 11 proceedings under the bankruptcy code would give the debtor in possession typically at least 18 months of continued operation before he had to satisfy any type of claims.
At the end of 18 months, he had to come into court with what we'd call a plan of reorganization of saying,
I'm going to pay off the secured creditors $0.25 on the dollars.
The unsecured creditors, I'm going to give them $0.05 on the dollar, and so on.
So debtor in possession left the same management in the companies for much longer periods of time than it had previously.
That was destructive to the industry?
Oh, I don't know that it was so destructive.
It just changed the way that you functioned in bankruptcy court.
We didn't go through near as many liquidations after that particular change.
I can't say that it's good or bad.
How did the changes in the tax law in 1986 change the way we do business?
And was 1986 the end of the 70% windfall tax?
Yes, because when the price of oil went down, there was no oil being taxed above that level, so there was no need for a windfall profits tax, and it was phased out.
Some of the things that have hurt, they phased out, maybe in the late 70s, early 80s, they phased out depletion allowance for all major oil companies.
It had been 27.5% of gross income that was not taxed.
It went to 15%, and then they took it to 0% for a major.
Independence still had it.
Then they put in preference tax items where all intangible drilling costs could not be deducted.
It had to be capitalized.
I don't think that the change in tax laws, it had an impact, a negative impact on the industry, but not an overwhelming impact.
I mean, they could have lived with,
if that was all that had been the problem.
So the oil industry paid more taxes, especially the big oil companies paid more taxes?
Yes.
I mean, question, because they totally lost their depletion amounts.
Have there been any debacles in foreign policy that have really screwed up our industry?
It's hard to say.
The accusation
has been, and there may be some element of proof, that during Desert Storm, we were not really there, the accusation is, to protect Kuwait.
Because Kuwait's got relatively few people, and there's a lot more injustices that have been done to people all over the world than there was in Kuwait.
What we were really over there for was to protect our oil supply that was coming out of Saudi Arabia.

I don't think that there's been any evidence to support it, but the allegation now from some corners is that Saudi made a deal to continue to produce at maximum rates since Desert Storm, since we sent our people over there really to protect their country.
Them producing at maximum rate has depressed the price of oil dramatically, and that was their deal, is that they said, okay, if you'll come over here and
and protect us.
We'll pump oil at a maximum rate.
The price of oil will stay way down.
You're importing a lot of oil, and that would be good for the United States.
It's very detrimental to the petroleum industry, but probably very favorable to the rest of the consumer.
I heard, as recently as last summer, that OPEC had adopted a long-term strategy of keeping the price of oil about $20.
so that alternative energy wouldn't develop and they could maintain a large energy market share for the long term.
Are they abandoning that strategy now?
Well, they certainly have on the short term.
OPEC and Saudi is producing at a very high rate.
They could run the price of oil back up to $20 a barrel if they'd shut back 5%.
But in the past,
Almost a year now, they have not done it.
Price of oil has been as low as $12, $13 a barrel in the United States.
Currently, the posted price is $17.
The actual field price is probably about $15, $16.
That's for West Texas?
Yes.
What's going to happen when Iraq comes online and then when the Soviet Union comes back online?
Well, let's talk about Iraq first.
If Iraq comes on and they can probably put as much as 3 million barrels a day, if nobody else cuts back, price will go to $10 a barrel.
If they were to come back on and OPEC kept their production rate very high, price of oil will plummet.
Soviet Union will not come back on.
I've been in Russia for over two months.
I've looked at hundreds and hundreds of wells
Their production went from 12 million barrels down to 6.5 million barrels.
Over what time?
Over about a four-year, five-year period.
The story that you read in the paper is that these wells have minor mechanical problems, and they just need a little help.
And the fact is that those wells have fatal flaw problems, is that they've got poor quality pipe.
Their cement jobs are almost nonexistent.
The only way to fix those wells is to plug them and totally re-drill them.
The Soviet Union, to get their production level back, probably needs a minimum of $50 billion of drilling activity.
Billion?
Billion.
How much did you say we spent?
We spent $160 billion over a six-year period.
And the Soviet Union needs a minimum of $50 billion, and at this point,
on any joint ventures formed over there, they've got a minimum of $6 a barrel tax on it.
So their tax rate is so high that they're simply not economical to drill in Russia today.
So they're asking American producers to produce at $6 a barrel?
Well, to start with, the Americans in the joint ventures are required to put up 100% of the money.
They only get half of the oil.
Just to start with, you're selling oil on the Black Sea for $9 a barrel.
You only get, I mean, for $18 a barrel, you only get half of it.
That's nine.
It costs $3 a barrel to transport it from Siberia, which is their major producing area, to the Black Sea.
So that leaves you with six.
Tax is $6 a barrel.
That leaves you with nothing.
And we haven't even talked about operating costs yet.
So there's not a lot of people rushing over there?
No.
Soviet production is not going to go back to 10 to 12 million barrels a day, in my opinion, in the foreseeable future.
Should the federal government do something to help oil companies get in over there, or should they do something to keep oil companies out?
Well, I don't know whether it should be the federal government's part.
worldwide economics dictate what should be done.
Obviously, if the government paves the way for big infusions of capital into the Soviet Union, that money is going to stay in the Soviet Union.
The problem with investments in the Soviet Union is that we have not seen any type of proposal where you're going to bring capital out of Russia.
Essentially, when you go over there and drill, then you're going to reinvest your cash flow into some type of Russia infrastructure, which is going to be refining transportation type of facilities.
So in effect, you're exporting a lot of US capital and a lot of US jobs to Russia, which are going to be filled by Russians, not by Americans.
There seems to be a movement in a lot of oil companies to produce abroad.
Yes.
And how does that affect U.S. jobs, and how does that affect U.S. tax revenue?
Well, we obviously are exporting jobs and exporting taxes to foreign countries.
It's just that simple.
Because once you spend the money over there, they're going to be taxed over there.
Those tax credits apply for U.S. taxes.
The U.S. might get some tax dollars, but it would be greatly diminished from what we would
if it were generated in the United States.
But also those jobs are exported.
When we go overseas and you go out location, you look at production facilities, at most you'll see 10% Americans.
You're going to see 90% of the people that are working there are nationals, which is probably what they should be.
But that means you just exported those jobs.
You also export the support people,
which is the dry cleaner, the grocery store, the filling station man.
You export the whole community overseas when you go into this type of thing.
What about equipment?
Are we exporting steel jobs?
Is the steel coming from somewhere else?
No.
Any country that is capable of producing steel or has ties to another company closer than they do to the United States will use steel from there.
For example, when you go into Russia,
you might bring in some steel from the United States.
But sooner or later, there's going to be a deal.
They'll have to get their steel up to specs.
They're going to insist on furnishing the pipe themselves.
They're going to do as much for themselves as they possibly can.
What Russia wants from the United States is one thing, money.
They don't want our technology.
They don't want advice.
They just want money.
They want to set up their own company.
That's correct.
And you pay for it.
So what does the industry look like for the next five years?
Industry will continue.
Domestic industry will continue to go through downsizing.
We will lose probably in the neighborhood of

eight percent to ten percent of our workforce each year the domestic budget will decline at the rate currently running about 20 billion dollars a year for production exploration it will decline also at about that same rate so we'll probably get down to a bedrock budget of around 10 billion dollars compared to the current 20 billion dollars
We're essentially going to continue to go through restructuring.
Major oil companies will continue to transfer oil properties by sales to mid-sized to smaller independent companies.
Will those independents explore or will they just produce?
No, they'll just produce out what we've got.
There will be very little exploration.
Do you expect the number of independents to grow?
Probably.
There is a size really that is a more efficient size.
When you get too small, you don't have the staff capability.
Probably the most efficient size of independent that is not going to explore is in the range of $50 to $150 million in assets.
That means about how many people?
Counting field people in the neighborhood of 50 to 150 people.
What about long term, the next 40 years?
